THE RELATION OF MALARIA TO ALTITUDE
THE Indian used Journal,
October, 1923,
by
C. A. Gill.

list.head: VII. SUMMARY.
list.item:
(1) Neither scarcity or absence of anophelines
nor unfavorable conditions of temperature, which have hitherto
been regarded as responsible for the rarity or absence of
malaria at high altitudes, account for the apparent freedom
from malaria of certain parts of the Himalayas in North-West
India at altitudes of 6,000-8,000 feet.

(2) Anopheline mosquitoes are prevalent in
Murree (7,500 feet) during at least five months in the year
(May--September), the most common species being A. willmori,
an efficient ‘carrier’ of malaria in Nature.

(3) The temperature prevailing in this hill
station is favourable to the occurrence of indigenous malaria
throughout the above period.

(4) Numerous human ‘carriers’ of malaria are
resident in Murree during the summer months, whilst the popu-
lation includes a high proportion of non-immunes.

(5) Anopheline mosquitoes (A. willmori) can be
experimentally infected at Murree with the benign tertian para-
site under conditions similar to those prevailing in Nature
during the months of July and August and infected insects are
-2-
capable of giving rise to acute malaria in a non-immune sub-
ject resident in Murree during the month of August.

(6) It is held that indigenous malaria probably
does not occur in Murree, but that, owing mainly to the influence
of relative humidity on the ‘carrier’ insect, the period during
which infection may be acquired is limited to approximately two
months. The failure to detect the occurrence of primary infec-
tions can be explained as due to the difficulty of determining
the source of infection, to the close resemblance frequently
existing between mild primary attacks and relapse attacks of
benign tertian malaria, and finally to the relative rarity of
these infections.

(7) It is concluded that primary infections ac-
quired in Murree, in addition to being relatively rare owing
to the limited opportunity of the spread of infection, will be
mild in character owing to the fact that they will be mainly if
not solely dependent upon the benign tertian parasite.

(8) Similar conditions to those prevailing in
Murree probably also occur in other hill stations in the
Himalayas at approximately similar altitudes and it is consequent-
ly concluded that the adoption of anti-malarial measures, such
as the use of mosquito nets in the case of children, may be more
necessary in these hill stations than has hitherto been supposed.

(9) It is concluded that the lessened frequency
and severity of malaria with increase in altitude is due to
correlated changes in atmospheric temperature and humidity with
occasion a lessened period of liability to infection and a pre-
dominance of benign tertian malaria in elevated regions.

(10) Altitude, through its influence on atmos-
pheric temperature and humidity, is held to be the main factor
determining the orographical distribution of indigenous malaria,
but no constant relationship would be expected to exist between
altitude and malaria since the temperature and humidity conditions
prevailing at any given altitude vary both with latitude and
with local physiographical features and meteorological conditions.
